moves.2. c4: I analyzed this game with Stockfish 9 at a 29 ply search depth, and it often prefers different opening moves than the ones played in the game.  For example, here it prefers 2. Nf3.
moves.5... Nxc3 6. bxc3 Bg7 7. Bc4: Stockfish: 7. Nf3 c5 8. Rb1 O-O 9. Be2 Nc6 10. d5 Bxc3+ 11. Bd2 Bxd2+ 12.  Qxd2 Na5 13. h4 or 13. Rc1 with just a tiny advantage for White.
moves.7... c5 8. Ne2: This is a line I like because it avoids any complications after 8. Nf3 O-O followed by Bg4.
moves.8... Nc6 9. Be3: For the next six moves, Stockfish thinks that Black's best option is to castle.
moves.11. Qd2:
We recently looked at this same opening sequence in a Magnus Carlsen bullet game. 

Stockfish: 11. Bd2 Qh5 12. O-O O-O 13. Bc3.
moves.11... e6 12. Qxa5 Nxa5 13. Bd3 b6 14. O-: Now 15... O-O 16. Rc7 Rfc8 17. Rac1 Rxc7 18.  Rxc7 Rc8 19. Rd7 Kf8 equal.
moves.16. Bd2:
Better is 16. Bb5+ Kd8 17. Bg5+ f6 18. Bf4 Rc8 19. Rxc8+ Bxc8 20. Rc1 with a really strong advantage.

Now Stockfish gives 16... Rhc8 17. Bb5+ Bc6 18. Ba6 Bb7 19. Bb5+ Ke7 equal.
moves.16... Nc6: White should play 17. e5 Rhc8 18.  a4 f6 19. f4.
moves.17... Nd4 18. Nxd4: Miniscule better is 18. Rab1 exd5 19. Nxd4 Bxd4 20. Bb5+ Kd6 21. Bf4+ Be5 22. Bxe5+ Kxe5 23. Rc7 Rab8 24. Rxf7.
moves.18... Bxd4 19. Bb5+ Kd6 20. Bb4+: After 20... Ke5 21. Rab1 Rac8 22. Rxc8 Rxc8 23. d6 Rd8 24. d7 Bc5 25. Bc3+ Bd4 26. Bb4 Bc5 is equal.
moves.21. Bxc5+ bxc5 22. dxe6 fxe6: Now 23. f3 Rab8 24. Bf1 Rhc8 25. Rc3 Rc7 26. Rd1+ Ke5 27. Rdc1 Rbc8 28. Ra3 a6 29. Kf2 with a strong advantage.
moves.23... Ke5: White has a slight advantage after 24. Rac1 Kxe4 25. Rxc5 Bd5 26. Bc6.
moves.24. f3: At the time my thinking was that I had the better pawn structure so I should prepare for the ending, which I thought would favor me.
moves.26. Ke3 g5: 27. h4 Rb8 28. Bd3 gxh4 29.  Rac1 Kd6 30. Rh1 Ra4 31. Bc4 Ba6 32. Bb3 and White is miniscule better.
moves.27. g3: Now Black is close to equal after 27... Rb8 28. Bd3 Rbd8 29. Rac1 Kd6 30. Rh1.
moves.27... Rad8: 28. Rd3 and White is a tiny bit better.
moves.28... gxf4+ 29. gxf4+ Kf6: White equalizes after 30. Rxd4 Rxd4 (30... cxd4+ 31. Kd3 equal.) 31. e5+ Kf5 32. Bd3+ Be4 33. Bf1 (33. Bb5 equal.) 33... Bd5 34. Bd3+ Be4.
moves.30. e5+: Doesn't help his problem on e4.
moves.30... Kf5 31. Bd3+: Now not 31... Kg4 32.  Rac1 with a slight advantage for White.
moves.31... Be4: Compared to the variation after 30. Rxd4, this is stronger because of the pin.
moves.32. Be2: After 32... Bc2 33. Rxd4 cxd4+ 34. Kd2 (Much worse is 34. Kf3 Be4+ 35. Kg3 (35. Kf2 Kxf4) 35... Rg8+) 34... d3 35. Bf1 Kxf4 36. Bh3 Kxe5 (36... Re8 37. Re1) 37. Re1+ Kd4 38. Rxe6 Rf8 Black still has a strong advantage
moves.32... Rd4xd1: I was unsure how this would turn out, but it favors White.
moves.33. Rxd1 Rxd1 34. Bxd1: If 34... Bd5 35.  Bc2+ (35. h3 Kg6 36. Bc2+ Kg7 equal.) 35... Kg4 36. Bxh7 and now 36... Bxa2 runs into problems after 37. Bg8 Kf5 38. Bf7 a5 39. h4.
moves.35. h3:
The key move.

If 35... h5 36. Bxh5.
moves.36. Bg4+ Kg6 37. Bxe6 h6 38. Bc4:
Hoping for 38. Bd3+ forcing a trade of bishops.

If 38... Kg7 39. a3 Kf8 40. Bd3 Ba2 41. f5 with a winning advantage.
moves.38... Kh5:
Loses more quickly.

How should White proceed?
